Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to meet financial independence requirement under paragraph 19(1)(b) of the Immigration Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether backlog class members must meet paragraph 19(1)(b) requirements for landing
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants in the backlog class relied on social assistance and subsidized housing, indicating inability to support themselves financially
Crimes.Court_Ruling: Court upheld the immigration officer's decision
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Members of the backlog class seeking landing status
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Immigration officer denied landing based on failure to meet financial independence requirement
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged exemption from paragraph 19(1)(b) due to backlog class status
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Interpretation of statutory requirements under the Immigration Act
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Ability to support oneself without reliance on public funds
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Scope of judicial review over immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Documentation of reliance on social assistance and subsidized housing
Crimes.Application_Basis: Inadmissibility due to lack of financial independence
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Paragraph 19(1)(b) requires ability to support oneself or demonstrate adequate care and support arrangements
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of proof of adequate financial support or care arrangements
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Denial of landing and permanent resident status
Crimes.Cause_Description: Applicants challenged their inadmissibility under paragraph 19(1)(b)
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Court assessed evidence of financial dependence on government assistance
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: Reliance on public benefits as evidence of inability to support oneself
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failure to meet conditions for admissible landing
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Application of immigration law to backlog class applicants
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Findings that applicants did not satisfy financial independence or alternative support requirements
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Exemption from visa requirements does not exempt from other admissibility criteria
Crimes.Decision_Making_Body: Immigration officer and Federal Court on judicial review
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Insufficient documentation of private financial support or care arrangements

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to meet statutory admissibility requirements
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether backlog class applicants are exempt from paragraph 19(1)(b) of the Immigration Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 6(2) of the Immigration Act and Backlog Regulations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants were denied landing due to inability to support themselves financially

Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Immigration officer determined applicants inadmissible under paragraph 19(1)(b)
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Assertion that backlog class members are exempt from financial independence requirements
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Statutory interpretation of exemptions under immigration regulations
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Existence of explicit regulatory exemption from paragraph 19(1)(b)
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Authority of immigration officers and scope of judicial review
Crimes.Review_Standard: Standard of statutory interpretation and administrative decision review
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Records showing reliance on social assistance and lack of independent financial means
Crimes.Application_Basis: Inability to support oneself without public assistance
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Financial circumstances and absence of private support mechanisms
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Granting of landing despite financial dependence
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Admissibility requires meeting all statutory criteria unless explicitly exempted
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No evidence of exemption or alternative support arrangements
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Denial of entry and permanent residence
Crimes.Cause_Description: Challenge to inadmissibility based on inability to support oneself
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Evaluation of financial records and benefit usage
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: Dependence on public funds as disqualifying factor
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failure to meet financial self-sufficiency requirement
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Application of general immigration rules to specific applicant classes
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Determination that applicants did not meet financial independence standard
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No regulatory exemption exists for backlog class applicants
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Lack of documentation proving financial independence or support plans
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Literal and purposive interpretation of statutory provisions
